text: The Mexican Revolution was brought on by a major armed struggle in Mexico that started in 1910 by an uprising led by Francisco I. MaderoJoseph, Gilbert and Jürgen Buchenau. Mexico's Once and Future Revolution. Durham: Duke University Press 2013, 1 against the long dictatorship of Porfirio Díaz.Gentleman, Judith. "Mexico since 1910". Encyclopedia of Latin American History and Culture, vol. 4, 15. Under his rule, power was concentrated in the hands of a select few, and the people had no power to express their opinions or to select their public officials.Friedrich Katz, The Secret War in Mexico. Wealth was likewise concentrated in the hands of the few, and injustice was everywhere in the cities and the countryside alikeLieuwen, Edwin. Mexican Militarism: The Political Rise and Fall of the Revolutionary Military. Westport: Greenwood Press 1981; reprint of University of New Mexico Press 1968 The revolution was characterized by several socialist, liberal, anarchist, populist, and agrarian movements. Over time, it changed from a simple revolt against the established order to a multi-sided civil war. There was less fighting after 1920, when Álvaro Obregón, the most important revolutionary leader who was still alive, became the president of Mexico. == References == Category:20th century in Mexico Category:20th-century rebellions Category:Civil wars Category:Revolutions Category:1910s conflicts Category:1920s conflicts Category:Wars involving North America
